captions.text:
Hi, I'm Kathy Santo for Iams
with Howdini, and today we're

going to talk about how to
leash train your puppy.

Once your puppy is around eight
weeks old, you can begin
leash training.

The first thing he'll need is a
collar or harness that fits

your puppy appropriately, never
too loose or too tight.

You should be able to fit two
fingers between the collar and
your puppy's neck.

When deciding between using a
collar or harness, there are
few things to consider.

Does your puppy have any
respiratory issues?

Does your puppy pull when
being walked on leash?

Use a harness or head halter if
your puppy pulls on leash
or has respiratory problems.

Before you can jump right in
training, you'll need to get

your puppy used to wearing a
collar and having the added
weight of a leash.

The best thing to do is have him
wear the collar or harness

and leash around the
house, so he
becomes used to the feeling.

Be sure to keep an eye on your
puppy to make sure he doesn't

get trapped, caught, or
accidentally injured.

If your puppy is noticeably
struggling or looks scared,

start off with a shoe lace or
a small piece of rope so he

can get used to dragging only
a little something around.

This will help him get used to
the added presence and weight
of a collar and leash.
Now for walking on a leash.

The leash should have
some slack.

Because when you put pressure on
a dog, their natural reflex

is to move or pull in the
opposite direction.

If you find that your puppy is
afraid of walking with the

leash, try placing treats
along the route you know

you'll be walking to give
him the notion that
good times are ahead.

That way he learns to focus on
what's ahead of him with
curiosity and not fear.

As you begin walking your puppy,
you will notice that

your pace will sometimes have
to be faster than you expect
to retain slack in the leash.

The more you work with your
puppy, the quicker you'll be

able to train him to
slow down while
maintaining the needed slack.

As you walk around, begin
incorporating specific
commands for your puppy.

Basic commands include sit,
stay, and heal, or let's go.

Do your best to remain
consistent with your commands

and guide your puppy through
the learning process.

For example, when you say sit,
guide your puppy to sit until

the command is recognized
by the puppy.

When you say heel, make sure
your puppy is obeying your

command before you start
walking again.

When your puppy starts to move
ahead too quickly, come to a

complete stop and wait for
him to cease pulling
before going forward.

Practice this stop and go, never
allowing your puppy to
dictate your pace.

If your puppy continues to pull
on his leash, ask him to

change directions while
saying turn.

This while condition your puppy
to always look for you

for direction instead of him
feeling like he can dictate
where the two of you go next.

I also like to run backwards
and then switch
to a different direction.

This gets your puppy excited
about chasing you.

Remember to reward your puppy
when he does the right thing

so that he begins to
understand what
you're asking him for.

If your puppy still isn't
catching on, try upgrading

your treats, practicing in an
area with fewer distractions,

or working on more
basic commands.

Leash training takes
time and patience.

Both you and your puppy may
give frustrated during the
learning process.
Do your best to avoid tugging.

It's not fair to correct them
for something they don't
understand.

As your dog enters adolescence
and clearly knows the

difference between right and
wrong, it's OK to give a

slight occasional tug
on his leash if he
insists on being difficult.

If you remain patient and
consistent with your puppy,

he'll be leashed trained
in no time.

I'm Kathy Santo for Iams with
Howdini and I hope that you've

found this helpful as you
welcome your new addition to
your family.

For more information on puppy
care and training, visit
iams.com/puppy.

title: Leash Training a Puppy: How to Leash Train a Puppy or Dog

comments.text:
I have an 8 week old puppy who acts nice when im around but when i leave to 
work he is stubborn with commands and barks back at my girlfriend. Any 
ideas?﻿
comments.author: 23indeed1

comments.text:
If your gf lives with you, make sure she is on board with having a puppy. 
The dog may be yours, but she is also the alpha dog in the house, so she 
needs to be willing to assert herself as another authority figure. Have her 
go with you to training classes and participate in training activities. Let 
her do things with the pup by herself, like you do, so you each build a 
personal relationship, but make sure all three of you do things together 
too so the pup doesn't try to work you against each other. When training, 
both humans need to be very patient. Sometimes it can take weeks or months 
for a dog to learn, but puppy needs to see both of you as the boss.
comments.author: MaiCohWolf

comments.text: Im thinkingbof a plan to convince my mam to get me a puppy﻿
comments.author: cameron bramley

comments.text:
Hi my puppy is 8weeks old. The first two days i walked with him it was ok 
but a challenge now he doesn't want to move unless i follow him. He also 
has a hard time responding to his name, any suggestion/ tip? ﻿
comments.author: 23indeed1

comments.text:
Try with a nickname for a little while and make sure he knows that that 
word means HIM. Some dogs hear their name so often, especially if they 
misbehave, that they don't actually know that is their name - they just end 
up thinking it's a word you happen to say a lot. Later, you can switch back 
to their actual name and retrain them to know BOTH names are theirs. 
My dog did not respond to her name all the time as a puppy and she ended up 
getting a lot of nicknames, but eventually she learned them all to be hers. 
We also talked to her with a high voice so that distinguished her from the 
rest of the family. She learned to pay attention anytime we raised the 
pitch of our voices. Poodles are notoriously easy to train though, so that 
could have played a major part. Just take your time and be patient, your 
pup will learn eventually. I had my dog for 13 years, so if you have any 
more questions I will try to help. Good luck!
comments.author: MaiCohWolf

comments.text:
Try being dominate  with your dog, no need for treats, put the collar all 
the way up, grab the leash as close to you, relax (don't pull, shoulders 
back and face up) and stay focused on walking forward, remember the key to 
have a balanced dog is exercise, disciple and love.
comments.author: Oscark 08

comments.text:
say his name often..and also have a quick session of clicker training him 
by giving him treats as soon as you tell his name...that should do it :) 
... sorry for my bad english :P

Put the collar all the way up, grab the leash as close to you and relax (no 
tension, shoulders back and head forward), stay FOCUSED on what you're 
doing, to get him to cross the street try getting him in the "zone" run 
around a little bit and as you feel the flow cross the street, your dog 
will never expect it, just don't run to much or he will heat up

comments.text: short or long leashes for puppies?﻿
comments.author: Taylor Scott

comments.text:
I suggest starting off with a short leash. One that can reach down to their 
height without choking them, but keeps them close to you. The idea is to 
train them to walk BESIDE you, rather than in front (dominant) or behind 
(slowing you down - also sometimes dominant). You could get a long leash, 
but hold most of the slack with you so the pup still learns to walk beside 
you. Good luck!
comments.author: MaiCohWolf

comments.text:
Ok it was the same with me and I got my dog walking finally! All you have 
do is put a leash on your dog and let him/her walk around the backyard with 
it for about 10 min to get used to it. go outside without your dog and get 
some food or treats and set them on the sidewalk but make sure they have 
you Put them far away from each other. then once your done take you dog 
outside and pull him/her/ and start walking and she will follow the food 
where it goes. Then next time you start walking and she sniffs and stops 
pull her and continue to walk. 
Hopefully this helped cause it helped me!

comments.text:
You shouldn't bring your dog to parks at 8 weeks. They have not had all 
their vaccinations and could get extremely sick and die. They need all 
three sets of shots to be safe, and most dogs are not fully vaccinated 
until sixteen weeks. You're putting your dog, and other dogs, at risk by 
doing this.

comments.text:
We had that problem at first. My puppy would just sit there and refused to 
move. However, he grew out of it just a week or two later. Now he likes 
following me. I didn't do anything specific, so it might just be a matter 
of age.
comments.author: Alexandra P

comments.text:
It's not "heal" it's "heel" because the command to "heel" comes from making 
your dog get behind you at your heels instead of walking in front of you. 
The better teaching is to make your dog learn that pulling on a leash makes 
them uncomfortable. They will learn not to pull on the leash anymore and to 
always stay very close to you. This tutorial says to walk quickly with a 
puppy because they will move fast. Definitely not! Teach your puppy that 
you lead, not them! All of this is so inaccurate!
comments.author: Jennifer Rustin

comments.text: Whatever you do, dont use a harness it will promote more pulling

comments.text:
my puppy is so bad when i put her on a leash all she does is whine and howl 
and she will tug on the lash so much i have to take it off! Any advice 
please????
comments.author: Ven0m456

comments.text:
We got a puppy three days ago. He will walk with me if he is not on a leash 
but if I put a leash on him he refuses to walk and just lays down. I've 
tried leaving the leash on in around the house he seems to have no problem 
that the leash and harness is on he seem to just not like the fact someone 
is holding the leash how do I get him to walk with my I've also tried 
treats and rewarding?
comments.author: alicia restad

comments.text:
We rescued a Pit Bull recently who is 7 months old. He pulls on his leash A 
LOT. He also chews on it while trying to walk him. Whats the best way to 
correct this?
comments.author: Chuck Trott

comments.text: That was a rhetorical question. They do.
comments.author: LilMissTravelPants

comments.text:
OK, start with very short walk. Like only on your driveway. Have your puppy 
keep her collar on at all times. Make sure you keep checking the size﻿ each 
day. Allow the leash to be on for certain time inside only while 
supervised﻿ to not allow her to get choked on furniture. It takes quite 
some time and a lot of patience.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text: so glad this is helpful.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
Be patient. Stop and hold the leash short and tight and say and firm word 
like "stay" or "No" or "Heel" whatever you want your command word to be.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
Please don't drag her. She will never want to go on a walk if you do this. 
Only start with very short walk. Like only on your driveway. Have your 
puppy keep her collar on at all times. Make sure you keep checking the size 
each day. Allow the leash to be on for certain time inside only while 
supervised﻿ to not allow her to get choked on furniture. It take quite some 
time and a lot of patience.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
Sorry for the delay. YT has issues with getting comments to us. Start by 
keeping collar on at all times. All leash to be on for certain time inside 
only while supervised to not allow her to get choked on furniture. It take 
quite some time and a lot of patience.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text: Keep the leash VERY short and tight. No slack.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
It take time for them to get used to it. Shot walks at first. I mean short. 
Like only in the driveway. Have them walk around a bit in the house with 
their leash on being careful that you watch them so they don't choke 
themselves.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text: Short walks. Short and tight leash. Do not let it get long and lengthy.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
This is a good idea. Just make sure your watch him so he does not get it 
snagged on furniture and choke himself. Or chew it to pieces.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text: Very short and brief walks. Keep the leash on a short tight lead.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text: Keep the leash short and tight so that it stay on one side of you.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text: No! Not at all!
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
I have a BIG question. My puppy doesn't like to walk, we try to walk and he 
lays down or sits. He doesn't like walks. How should I teach him how?
comments.author: sara4ever123

comments.text: I love the color if that leash!
comments.author: KairiX31

comments.text:
Be patient I'm in the same boat. What were we doing at 8 weeks old? Sucking 
our thumbs!
comments.author: SonoPina

comments.text: Thank you!
comments.author: Omar Brown

comments.text:
This is very helpful, thank you! my puppy is now 8 weeks old and we have 
begun to make trips to the dog park :)
comments.author: Caitlin Rose

comments.text:
how do i make my puppy follow only me when we take a walk? i mean because 
whenever he see passersby he will follow that person and when i stop 
him...he whines..what should i do?
comments.author: legendarykilljoyz
